item.title: Class destroyed: A look at what has become of Gaza's revered universities
item.dc:creator: Chantal Da Silva and Yasmine Salam and Matthew Mulligan and Bianca Britton
item.description: Built over decades, Gaza’s universities embodied the ambitions of young Palestinians. In weeks, the Israeli military destroyed them.

item.title: Israel to open more aid routes to Gaza and increase deliveries after pressure from Biden
item.dc:creator: Rebecca Shabad and Carol E. Lee and Peter Alexander and Monica Alba and Allie Raffa and Courtney Kube and Yuliya Talmazan and Yamiche Alcindor and Frank Thorp V and Alexandra Bacallao and Zoë Richards and Rebecca Kaplan
item.description: Israel committed to taking new steps that would boost the flow of aid into Gaza after a call between President Joe Biden and Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu on Thursday.

media:content.media:text: President Joe Biden
media:content.media:description: President Joe Biden on Oct. 18, 2023, in Tel Aviv.

media:content.media:text: oval office white house desk telephone
media:content.media:description: President Joe Biden speaks with Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu via telephone from the Oval Office of the White House, on Thursday.

item.title: Earthquake showed Taiwan was well prepared for a big one — more so than parts of U.S.
item.dc:creator: Evan Bush
item.description: The powerful earthquake in Taiwan demonstrated the effectiveness of the country's early warning system and seismic infrastructure.

media:content.media:text: 7.3 Magnitude Earthquake Hits Taiwan
media:content.media:description: A partially collapsed building in Taiwan on April 3, 2024, after a powerful earthquake.

media:content.media:text: A California Highway Patrol officer checks the damage to cars that fell when the upper deck of the Bay Bridge collapsed onto the lower deck after the Loma Prieta earthquake in San Francisco on Oct. 17, 1989.
media:content.media:description: A California Highway Patrol officer checks the damage to cars that fell when the upper deck of the Bay Bridge collapsed onto the lower deck after the Loma Prieta earthquake in San Francisco on Oct. 17, 1989.

media:content.media:text: A damaged building in Hualien City, Taiwan, after an earthquake
media:content.media:description: A damaged building Tuesday in Hualien City, Taiwan.

item.title: Biden and Netanyahu to hold first call since Israeli strikes killed World Central Kitchen workers
item.dc:creator: Monica Alba and Zoë Richards
item.description: President Joe Biden and Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu are expected to speak by phone on Thursday, according to a U.S. official with knowledge of the call.

media:content.media:text: President Joe Biden, left, meets with Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu
media:content.media:description: President Joe Biden, left, meets with Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, right, to discuss the the war between Israel and Hamas, in Tel Aviv, Israel, on Oct. 18, 2023.

item.title: Displeasure with Biden's handling of Hamas-Israel war was on display at closed-door White House meeting
item.dc:creator: Monica Alba and Yamiche Alcindor and Elyse Perlmutter-Gumbiner
item.description: Just five minutes into a meeting with President Joe Biden, a Palestinian American doctor who has treated gravely injured patients in Gaza couldn’t bear to stay, so he left.

media:content.media:text: Protester pray in the rain outside the White House.
media:content.media:description: Demonstrators outside the White House as they gather to call for a ceasefire in Gaza outside the White House on April 2, 2024.

item.title: Biden 'outraged' by Israeli strike that killed aid workers in Gaza
item.dc:creator: Megan Lebowitz
item.description: The president's statement — his first comments on the deaths of World Central Kitchen humanitarian workers — contained some of his strongest criticism of Israel.

media:content.media:text: President Joe Biden delivers remarks at the White House
media:content.media:description: President Joe Biden in the Roosevelt Room of the White House on March 26, 2024.

item.title: She secretly educated herself to escape Afghanistan. Now, she's working to help women still there
item.dc:creator: Maya Eaglin
item.description: Sola Mahfouz stopped going to school in 2007 when she was an 11-year-old living in Afghanistan.

item.title: Meet the families who've taken children as young as 2 to Everest Base Camp
item.dc:creator: Aria Bendix
item.description: A handful of families have taken children as young as 2 years old to Mount Everest Base Camp in recent years. Three of them describe the experience.

media:content.media:text: Hazel Matulis at Everest Base Camp in 2022.
media:content.media:description: Hazel Matulis at Everest Base Camp in 2022.

media:content.media:text: Dimple Laddha took her daughter, Arishka, last year when Arishka was just 6 years old.

media:content.media:text: Chris and Cindy Matulis with their kids at Everest Base Camp in 2022.

item.title: Looking for leads, not love: Job seekers in China turn Tinder into a networking tool
item.dc:creator: Larissa Gao and Helen Chen
item.description: Young people in China facing an increasingly tough labor market are turning to an unlikely place for help in their job searches: Tinder.

media:content.media:text: Photo Illustration: A man's Tinder profile reads "Looking for Full-tim employment"
media:content.media:description: Some young people in China see Tinder as a way to find potential job leads.

media:content.media:text: China Youth Unemployment
media:content.media:description: University students at a job fair in Wuhan, China, in March.

item.title: How the Israel-Hamas conflict has spread beyond the Mideast
item.dc:creator: Alexander Smith and JoElla Carman and Jiachuan Wu
item.description: Four months into the war, fighting has spread from Gaza to Pakistan.

item.title: Desperate search for trapped earthquake victims in Taiwan
item.description: With at least 10 dead from the powerful quake, the search intensified for dozens of people who are missing and may be trapped in the rubble. NBC News' Janis Mackey Frayer reports.

media:content.media:title: Desperate search for trapped earthquake victims in Taiwan
media:content.media:description: With at least 10 dead from the powerful quake, the search intensified for dozens of people who are missing and may be trapped in the rubble. NBC News' Janis Mackey Frayer reports.

item.title: Biden takes tougher tone in phone call with Israel's Netanyahu
item.description: The White House said President Biden told Israel's Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu that more trucks must be let into Gaza to deliver aid, and that Israel must take concrete steps to protect civilians. The call followed the killing of seven people working for Chef Jose Andres's World Central Kitchen. NBC News' Gabe Gutierrez reports.

media:content.media:title: Biden takes tougher tone in phone call with Israel's Netanyahu
media:content.media:description: The White House said President Biden told Israel's Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu that more trucks must be let into Gaza to deliver aid, and that Israel must take concrete steps to protect civilians. The call followed the killing of seven people working for Chef Jose Andres's World Central Kitchen. NBC News' Gabe Gutierrez reports.

item.title: Brothers half a world apart start Gaza soup kitchen to feed those caught in war
item.description: Hani Almadhou lives in Virginia and his brother Mahmoud lives in Gaza. Though living far apart, they have created a vital soup kitchen to feed the people of Gaza and have raised $260,000 to keep it going. NBC News' Monica Alba reports.

media:content.media:title: Brothers half a world apart start Gaza soup kitchen to feed those caught in war
media:content.media:description: Hani Almadhou lives in Virginia and his brother Mahmoud lives in Gaza. Though living far apart, they have created a vital soup kitchen to feed the people of Gaza and have raised $260,000 to keep it going. NBC News' Monica Alba reports.

item.title: Gazan father bids tearful farewell to dead wife and daughters
item.description: NBC News filmed the emotional scene at a Rafah hospital as a wounded man cried over the bodies of his pregnant wife and two of his three children, killed in an Israeli airstrike. “There isn’t any safety at all in the Gaza Strip,” said one witness. “There isn’t any meter or an inch of land that is safe.”

media:content.media:title: Gazan father bids tearful farewell to dead wife and daughters
media:content.media:description: NBC News filmed the emotional scene at a Rafah hospital as a wounded man cried over the bodies of his pregnant wife and two of his three children, killed in an Israeli airstrike. “There isn’t any safety at all in the Gaza Strip,” said one witness. “There isn’t any meter or an inch of land that is safe.”

item.title: Yellen kicks off China meetings with overcapacity concerns
item.dc:creator: Evelyn Cheng, CNBC
item.description: Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen kicked off her first full day of official meetings in China discussing overcapacity concerns and market-oriented reforms.

media:content.media:text: Image: *** BESTPIX *** CHINA-US-DIPLOMACY
media:content.media:description: Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen, left, with Chinese Vice Minister of Finance Liao Min and U.S. Ambassador to China Nicholas Burns in Guangzhou, China, on Thursday.

item.title: Charging elephant kills elderly American woman on safari tour
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mulligan and Yuliya Talmazan and Rebecca Cohen
item.description: An American woman who was on what she had called her "last big trip" was killed when a charging elephant flipped over the car she was traveling in at a national park in Zambia.

media:content.media:text: African Bull Elephant Kills Tourist
media:content.media:description: An African bull elephant charges toward a tourist vehicle in the Kafue National Park in Zambia on March 30, 2024.

media:content.media:text: Gail Mattson, during a safari in Zambia
media:content.media:description: Gail Mattson.

item.title: Mercury exposure is widespread among Yanomami tribe in Amazon, a report finds
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press
item.description: BRASILIA, Brazil — Many Yanomami, the Amazon’s largest Indigenous tribe in relative isolation, have been contaminated with mercury coming from widespread illegal gold mining, according to a report released on Thursday by Brazil’s top public health institute.

media:content.media:text: A Brazil Environmental Agency helicopter flies over an illegal mining camp
media:content.media:description: A Brazil Environmental Agency helicopter flies over an illegal mining camp during an operation to try to contain it in Yanomami Indigenous territory in Brazil in 2023.

item.title: Mexico’s likely next president is a scientist. Politics has her mostly quiet on climate threats.
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press
item.description: Mexico's likely next president, Claudia Sheinbaum co-authored the Nobel-winning Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change report, but her political mentor, President López Obrador, has pushed fossil fuels and she's been quiet on global warming.

media:content.media:text: Claudia Sheinbaum greets supporters during a rally
media:content.media:description: Claudia Sheinbaum at a rally at in Mexico City on April 1, 2024.

media:content.media:text: Claudia Sheinbaum poses for a selfie with supporters
media:content.media:description: Claudia Sheinbaum with supporters during a campaign rally in Tlaquepaque, Mexico, on April 3.

item.title: South African soccer star and Olympian Luke Fleurs killed in hijacking
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press
item.description: JOHANNESBURG — South African footballer and Olympian Luke Fleurs has been killed in a hijacking in Johannesburg, his Kaizer Chiefs club said on Thursday.

media:content.media:text: Luke Fleurs
media:content.media:description: Luke Fleurs in a match between Supersport United and Richards Bay in Atteridgeville, South Africa, on Jan. 22, 2023.

item.title: U.N. rights body adopts first resolution to protect rights of intersex people
item.dc:creator: Reuters
item.description: The United Nations Human Rights Council voted to adopt a resolution designed to protect the rights of intersex people, the first initiative of its kind.

media:content.media:text: An intersex-inclusive Pride flag is waved during the annual Christopher Street Day parade on July 22, 2023 in Berlin, Germany.
media:content.media:description: An intersex-inclusive Pride flag is waved during the 2023 Christopher Street Day parade in Berlin.

item.title: At least 27 dead as militants attack Iran security forces, state media reports
item.dc:creator: Reuters
item.description: Suspected Sunni Muslim militants killed at least 11 Iranian security force members and suffered 16 fatalities state media said on Thursday.

item.title: Myanmar fighters target military in drone attacks on capital, anti-junta groups say
item.dc:creator: Reuters
item.description: Opponents of army rule in Myanmar said on they carried out drone attacks on two military targets in its capital Naypyitaw.

media:content.media:text: A soldier patrols the street in front of the Central Bank
media:content.media:description: A soldier patrols the street during a demonstration in Yangon, Myanmar on Feb 15, 2021.

item.title: Zimbabwe declares drought disaster, the latest in a region where El Nino has left millions hungry
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press
item.description: Zimbabwe declared a state of disaster over a drought that’s sweeping across much of southern Africa, with the president saying it needs $2 billion in aid.

media:content.media:text: Zimbabwe declared a state of disaster Wednesday, April 3, 2024, over a devastating drought that's sweeping across much of southern Africa, with the country’s president saying it needs $2 billion for humanitarian assistance.
media:content.media:description: James Tshuma, a farmer in Mangwe district in southwestern Zimbabwe, stands in the middle of his dried up crop field last month.

media:content.media:text: A new drought has left millions facing hunger in southern Africa as they experience the effects of extreme weather that scientists say is becoming more frequent and more damaging.
media:content.media:description: Women share peas during a food aid distribution in Mangwe southwestern Zimbabwe last month.

item.title: NATO marks its 75th birthday as Russia's war in Ukraine gnaws at its unity
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press
item.description: NATO marked on Thursday 75 years of collective defense across Europe and North America, with its top diplomats vowing to stay the course in Ukraine as better armed Russian troops assert control on the battlefield.

media:content.media:text: Nato 75th Anniversary
media:content.media:description: NATO Secretary General Jens Stoltenberg, center, attenda the alliance's 75th anniversary at its headquarters in Brussels on Thursday.

media:content.media:text: NATO 75th Anniversary
media:content.media:description: The signing of the North Atlantic Pact in Washington, D.C., on April 4, 1949.

media:content.media:text: The NATO military alliance on April 4, 2024, marks the 75th anniversary of the signing of its founding treaty in Washington.
media:content.media:description: Secretary of State Antony Blinken claps with other delegates as they listen to speeches at the NATO Headquarters in Brussels on Thursday.

item.title: Janet Yellen set to arrive in China amid overcapacity concerns
item.dc:creator: Evelyn Cheng, CNBC
item.description: Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen was scheduled to arrive in China on Thursday ahead of four full days of meetings with Chinese officials.

media:content.media:text: economy finance treasury secretary Janet Yellen
media:content.media:description: Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen is making her second trip to China in less than a year.
